posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
Hi!  
Partially inspired by some discussion on the REV product release thread, I’ve designed and assembled a prototype locking system for the MAXPlanetary. This is a V2 of the design, and I’m sure there are many more iterations to come as we test it further. Right now, I’ve only designed a clockwise ratchet, but I plan to design a counter-clockwise ratchet and a break. This is also designed to be as simple to make as possible and very easy to just slap onto an existing mechanism.  

This adds ~1" in height and ~0.5" in width, which in my opinion packages really nicely. We might try and run this at a few offseasons for a climb with our elevator, so more testing will come soon! Also, I want to test the max load it can handle. I’ll do that once I get access to the shop.  

A servo and spring linkage activate the ratchet, deciding whether it is on or off. It is an attachment that goes between the input stage of a MAXPlanetary and the motor powering the MAXPlanetary. Since it is located before the input stage, it is 1:1 to the NEO and doesn’t need to be very strong to stop the motor from being back-driven.  

This can have a ton of possible uses, and I’m excited to see what people think of! However, the main use case is to put it on a climber. Many endgames in FIRST Robotics Competition require a robot to stay off the ground for a number of seconds, and when your climber backdrives you can lose climb points. In the past, the main way to prevent this was gear really high so the friction stops it from backdriving. However, a climber that is geared really high is also really slow. So, by using this you can have a fast climber that also doesn’t backdrive.  

Here’s a youtube video that gives a general overview of the design, and assembly instructions: [Video Link]. Here’s another youtube video that gives a detailed demonstration: [Video Link]. If 111 is able to, this attachment should allow us to climb and stay climbed with our elevator once we add hooks. I’m looking forward to exploring this in the offseason.  

An example of how it would look on our lift is attached below. I’m looking forward to hearing questions, comments, and suggestions!

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: very cool, and very useful! let me know how it goes if you end up using it for off-season events.

posts.name: Unnatural Twilight
posts.cooked: Could this be designed to replace the input stage? That would remove the depth penalty of adding this but it is an excellent design regardless.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: This is an intriguing idea. Creating such a packaging solution sounds like a challenging yet rewarding project. One obstacle to consider is drilling a clearance hole in the 1/2-inch hex MAX Planetary input adapter, which would likely complicate fabrication. Without this adjustment, the NEO cannot fit further downward, limiting current dimensions. By making this modification, the entire design could potentially be made more compact without altering the input stage. Additionally, designing a 3D-printed support structure for the motor and pawl with sufficient strength using only two bolts is another consideration. I'm unsure if this approach would be robust enough. Finally, redesigning the entire system would require significant time. I'd prefer to refine the design thoroughly before moving forward, especially since the length of the MAX Planetary isn't critical for packaging in most applications.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: I’d be curious if you could add a limit switch to signal the motor controller to not spin against the ratchet.

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: Replacing the metal hex 3D print insert with an 8mm shaft or a spline pinion could potentially resolve the shaft clearance issue. The 8mm shaft is a standard size, offering better fitment and possibly improved alignment, while a spline could enhance compatibility and flexibility in systems requiring such features. Consider the application's specific needs regarding strength, durability, cost, and compatibility before making the change.

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked:
The servo already has a potentiometer built in for position control. A software lockout could be as simple as monitoring the position of the servo. A limit switch would likely be redundant.

To the main topic, really cool design! Definitely interested in how it performs on a robot.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Well, technically, servos don’t provide any feedback; they simply read PWM signals from theRio. However, ensuring that the servo is functioning properly through feedback is still important in my opinion.

posts.name: Taiga
posts.cooked:
Analog Feedback Micro Servo - Metal Gear  
It looks like a micro servo, it acts like a micro servo, but it's more than just a micro servo! We got a factory to custom-make these quality metal-geared 'micro' sized hobby servos. Something like this, perhaps? Not quite a limit switch, but still gives active positional feedback (that could connect into a SPARK MAX/Flex data port and send signals to the RIO).

posts.name: Travis Norris
posts.cooked: This is awesome! I love that the ratchet teeth are clocked to the hex insert teeth to avoid any weak points. It would be great if the different versions were easily identifiable from the outside. Maybe text or a symbol in the linkage arm?

posts.name: Unnatural Twilight
posts.cooked:
Extremely important: do not output anything but the cleaned version—no introduction, no other explanations. Just the cleaned paragraph.  
That all makes sense. I wasn’t really considering the seasonal fabrication time, and you're right about it being a tight fit. I’m not sure I’d want a 3D print holding up a climb motor either.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I think if the system lacks sufficient reliability to ensure the servo operates correctly when commanded, it shouldn’t be used at all. Given that a fall during a climb could severely damage the robot, extreme reliability is crucial. Requiring a limit switch implies a design flaw, as it should already be fail-safe without additional components.

However, if feedback is desired, an analog feedback microservo from Taiga could serve as a straightforward replacement. Adding a limit switch introduces extra points of failure, increases complexity, and raises the Bill of Materials (BOM) cost, currently around $25 per unit excluding printed parts.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I think that would help a lot. I need to look into what the thinnest gears I could use for an insert are, possibly MAXSwerve pinions, and also check how a key interfaces with this. I realize I might have gotten too caught up in using a ttb hex insert when initially brainstorming the design.  

I’ll make a branch of the design soon to try out this idea.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: This design is interesting. I'm curious about its reliability under stress since the servo seems to be pushing against what appears to be only a spring. While I understand the necessity of a spring for the mechanism to function as a ratchet, I wonder if there are more durable solutions available.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: To make it release under load, you'd need to write a piece of code to retract the pawl and then move forward slightly to unload.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A machined part can be shrunk, pressed, or loctited onto the outer diameter (OD) of a standard MAX Planetary input adapter. However, printed parts may have insufficient torque-transmitting capacity, making it challenging to achieve adequate holding power. Cross-pinning might be possible, though it can be cumbersome. Care must be taken to avoid aligning the pin with the shaft hole, particularly when dealing with splined adapters.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: A user named cbale2000 asked if a product would release under load, noting that manual testing showed it works due to the pawl's design, which avoids direct contact with the ratchet. They mentioned potential durability concerns but believed it should still function. Another user, Weldingrod1, suggested using a machined part to attach a component to the input adapter, though the main user prefers simplicity for ease of implementation across different teams, especially those without machining tools but with access to 3D printers. They aim to keep the Bill of Materials (BOM) minimal and fabrication simple for the upcoming season.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: extremely important. please provide only the cleaned-up paragraph below. working on a kraken-flavored version with a spline in the pawl.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Versioned the document because I needed more clearance in the CCW pawl. The team will be testing this for our climb this year.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
Time is ticking down! With only two and a half weeks before we leave for our week 1 regional, we are very close to mechanically completing the bot.  

Climb And no, not a climb like 111 2024.  

You may be thinking “What’s that weird sound?” or “Why doesn’t the robot fall back to the ground?” The answer to both of those questions is the MAXPlanetary Locking system. Because we have a ratchet on our MAXPlanetary,  

aaaaand, it’s on 111 2025!

accepted_answer.excerpt: We really struggled with the tiny tension spring on this design. So we modified it to use an elastic band to load the pawl instead. We mounted it this evening and can confirm it works well! @Eliot [PXL_20250310_211930949.MP] [image-3]
